author: Chloe Chaplain
title: Hundreds of London Routemaster buses recalled after fault causes rear doors open mid-journey
text:
Thousands march to Downing Street in protest at Trump's travel ban 
Hundreds of Boris Johnson’s Routemaster buses are being recalled after it was discovered the rear doors open when the bus is moving. 
More than 400 of the vehicles are being recalled after the Department for Transport found it is possible for the doors to open without warning on a moving bus, causing it to suddenly stop. 
The buses now require a software update but Transport for London said it would be paid for by the manufacturers. 
The controversial buses faced criticism when introduced by former Mayor Mr Johnson in 2012 after it was revealed they cost £50,000 more than other hybrid models. 
And in December the current Mayor of London, Sadiq Khan , announced that no more Routemasters would be purchased. Door fault: The buses have been recalled for a software update (Picture: Glenn Copus) 
Florence Eshalmi, Labour London Assembly spokeswoman for Transport, said: “Just when you think it can’t get any worse for the Routemasters here we have yet another example of the previous Mayor’s vanity project costing Londoners dear. Ticket office staff will not join Tube strike, union says 
“An ‘eco-friendly’ bus that ended up running on diesel, and a ‘hop on hop off’ service that was too expensive to manage. 
“Sauna like conditions in the summer that led to windows being replaced, and now rear doors that can open without warning when the bus is moving. 
“This really is beyond farcical. 
“I am pleased Mayor Khan has already announced no more of these overpriced vehicles will be purchased, but I will be raising the issue of any public costs associated with the latest recall at Transport Committee in City Hall this week.” 'Vanity project': The buses were introduced by former Mayor Boris Johnson (Oli Scarff/Getty Images) 
But Gareth Powell, TfL’s director of strategy and contracted services, told the Standard that Wrightbus would be carrying out the update and it would not cost TfL anything. Read more
